import React from 'react'; import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom'; import LessonCard from '../LessonCard'; const PhishingLesson = () => { const navigate = useNavigate(); return (

Phishing is a type of cyberattack in which attackers impersonate legitimate organizations or individuals to deceive people into revealing sensitive information, such as passwords, credit card numbers, or other personal details. Phishing attacks can occur through emails, social media, phone calls, or even fake websites.

Scenario: You receive an email seemingly from your CEO, asking you to urgently purchase gift cards for a charity event. The email appears legitimate, using the CEO's name and email address, but the urgency and the unusual request are red flags.

Types of Phishing Attacks

  • Email Phishing: The most common form of phishing, where attackers send fraudulent emails pretending to be from trusted sources to trick individuals into revealing personal information or downloading malware.
  • Spear Phishing: This is a more targeted form of phishing, where attackers customize their emails to a specific individual or organization, often gathering information from social media to make the emails appear more legitimate.
  • Smishing: Phishing via SMS, where attackers send text messages claiming to be from banks, government agencies, or other trusted entities, tricking people into clicking malicious links or providing personal information.
  • Vishing: Phishing over the phone, where attackers impersonate legitimate organizations and ask for personal details.

Signs of a Phishing Email

  • Suspicious sender address: Check the sender's email address carefully. Phishing emails often come from addresses that look similar to legitimate ones but have small differences (e.g., “secure.bank.com” vs “secure.bank0.com”).
  • Generic greetings: Phishing emails may use general greetings like “Dear Customer” instead of addressing you by your name.
  • Urgent requests: Phishing emails often create a sense of urgency, pressuring you to take immediate action (e.g., “Your account has been compromised. Click here to secure it now!”).
  • Suspicious links or attachments: Phishing emails contain links that lead to fake websites designed to steal your information, or they may contain attachments that can infect your computer with malware.
  • Grammatical errors: Phishing emails often contain spelling or grammar mistakes that would be uncharacteristic of a legitimate organization.

What to Do if You Suspect a Phishing Attack

  • Do not click on any links or download attachments: If the email seems suspicious, avoid clicking any links or downloading attachments.
  • Verify the sender: Contact the person or organization directly using a phone number or email address you trust, not the contact information provided in the email.
  • Report it: Many companies have dedicated email addresses for reporting phishing attempts. You can also forward phishing emails to organizations like the Anti-Phishing Working Group (APWG) at reportphishing@apwg.org.
  • Use email filters: Many email providers offer phishing filters that automatically mark suspicious emails as spam.
  • Keep your software updated: Ensure your operating system and security software are up to date to protect yourself from malware and viruses delivered by phishing emails.

Preventing Phishing Attacks

To minimize your risk of falling victim to phishing attacks, consider the following steps:

  • Use strong, unique passwords: Avoid using the same password for multiple sites. Consider using a password manager to securely store your passwords.
  • Enable two-factor authentication (2FA): 2FA adds an extra layer of security by requiring something you know (your password) and something you have (e.g., a code sent to your phone).
  • Educate yourself and others: Awareness is key. Regularly educate yourself and your team on how to recognize phishing attempts and stay updated on the latest phishing tactics.
  • Be cautious when sharing information: Always verify that a request for sensitive information is legitimate, even if it appears to come from a trusted source.
 ); }; export default PhishingLesson;
